attachments.title: How Could Google's New Logo Be Only 305 Bytes When Its Old Logo Was 14,000 Bytes?
attachments.text: The old logo uses a complicated serif font which can only be created using bezier curves. All together, it has 100 anchor points, resulting in a 6 KB (6,380 bytes) file. When compressed, the size comes down to 2 KB (2,145 bytes).
attachments.fallback: Gizmodo: How Could Google's New Logo Be Only 305 Bytes When Its Old Logo Was 14,000 Bytes?

I have been using the "The Great Suspender” chrome extension for about two weeks and it’s amazing. It suspends tabs that you haven’t used for a while, and you can reload them easily if you need to.
It’s amazing if you use tabs as a sort of reading list like I do

attachments.title: BERC Cleanweb Hackathon 3.0
attachments.text: BERC Cleanweb Hackathon 3.0: Data-drive solutions for resource problems Friday Oct 23 5pm until Saturday Oct 24 9pm Calling all scientists, software engineers, policy makers, designers, and entrepreneurs: please join us for the 3rd annual BERC Cleanweb Hackathon! The goal of the hackathon is to address a resource problem (energy, land, or water) using visualizations or software. Food and beverage will be provided by BERC. To be hosted at the Berkeley Institute for Data Science, a new amazing collaborative working space located in the beautiful Doe Library on UC Berkeley's campus. Prizes: $1000: best visualization to support policy and action; $1000: best software addressing barriers to progress; $500: people's choice! Full rules and description to be released soon on DevPost.

recommended - they have some cool stuff :simple_smile:
For all the years I've been in the bay area, I actually haven't been to a hackathon before -- I'm hoping to remedy the issue sometime soon.
Not sure if I'll stop by for this one or not, but I'm thinking about it.

<@U0A6T0LNT>: I put in some work cleaning and translating it into a "database" of sorts that I was comfortable with. I got bogged down when I started exploring the parameter space of all the different learning algorithms I could use to generate terrain from a starting sample patch. That is where it currently sits, with time having been re-directed towards UCB4B and organizing this year's SF Journey to the End of the Night on Halloween.
<@U0AVA8KDH>: what sort of data/algorithm are you interested in using to generate terrain?

It's not necessarily best-suited to the problem, but I was trying a variety of neural network approaches (particularly interested in recurrent neural networks to play around with the idea of "memory"). If I were trying to get it done as fast as possible in a way I best understand, I'd probably manually extract various probabilities from the national data set and use it in an iterated seeding approach (not really sure if that name makes sense...)
ahh, so you want to generate realistic terrain from a set of rules derived from the real terrain in the US
what sorts of data layers are you interested in including?

Provisionally, I was going to start purely with elevation data. From there, there's some really cool datasets for things like water cover, land use, species distribution, and tree canopy I bookmarked, and imagine it wouldn't be too hard to find information on seasons, temperature, precipitation, plant hardiness zones,  etc.
But yeah, I'd be happy with just elevation to start :stuck_out_tongue_winking_eye:
That emoticon was not what I expected O_O
hahah
what kind of structure did you put the cleaned data into?
Generally what type of data is this that you're looking at?  What's being represented, and in what format?
I'm guessing latitude/longitude and then a bunch of information about that point in space? (elevation, land use, &etc)

Right now, the NGTOC data I have is the elevation (in meters) at 10m intervals across the entire US. Space and speed wasn't a huge concern for me, so I used this as an opportunity to experiment with a few different storage options and settled on hdf5 a la h5py. The files are literally just gigantic dumps of elevation values, locations for the exact starting lat/long coordinate is given in each file name, and it proceeds at 10 m intervals from there.
<http://ngtoc.usgs.gov/>

<@U0A6T0LNT> do you think Ubuntu is still the best distribution to get someone new started on Linux? I had some first years asking me questions about it.
for an introduction to scientific computing, I recommend the Berkeley (Common/Collaborative/Compute...) Environment, which is based on Ubuntu
regardless of your operating system, you can spin up the BCE virtual machine in VirtualBox
and it's preconfigured with all of the basics + some really sophisticated stuff
<http://bce.berkeley.edu/>
it's also really trivial to spin up a BCE virtual machine on Amazon Web Services
I am not involved with much in the way of high performance cloud stuff
but we had a workshop last week where we all sat down with our laptops and we were cloud computing in minutes

I have Ubuntu 15.05 Mate Edition running on a Raspberry Pi 2 and I really like it

I got into it a couple of years back when Ubuntu was going through some growing pains when it was trying to transition over the Unity desktop environment.  I hear that they're getting their act together again, but Linux Mint does a pretty good job of hitting the "just works out of the box" mark for most things that I need to do.

attachments.title: New design points a path to the 'ultimate' battery
attachments.text: Scientists have developed a working laboratory demonstrator of a lithium-oxygen battery which has very high energy density, is more than 90% efficient, and, to date, can be recharged more than 2000 times, showing how several of the problems holding back the development of these devices could be solved.
attachments.fallback: New design points a path to the 'ultimate' battery

text: Lithium-Air batteries are the real deal
IF we can make them work
<https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lithium%E2%80%93air_battery>
"A lithium-air battery has an energy density (per kilogram) comparable to gasoline."
and for all of you non-chemists out there, that is _*insane*_
a standard lead-acid car battery has an energy density of 0.17 megajoules per kilo
automotive gasoline has an energy density of *45 megajoules per kilo*
a lithium-ion battery is more like 0.5 MJ/kg
only about 15% of gasoline's energy reaches the road due to the thermodynamics of a heat engine (Carnot efficiency and all that)

so though Li-air has a slightly lower maximum theoretical density than gasoline and batteries have lots of nonidealities, electric motors aren't bound by Carnot efficiency and it should be possible to get the same amount of energy to the road
the lab designs I've read about get clogged up with lithium oxidation side-products
and have electrochemical issues that make them charge very inefficiently
a bunch of people in my class work on lithium-air, lithium-sulfur, <https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lithium%E2%80%93sulfur_battery>
and solid polymer electrolyte batteries <https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lithium_polymer_battery>
Interesting but not yet exciting.
If we can get it to work it would be incredible for electric cars. Less so for grid applications where weight is almost irrelevant.
<@U0A6T0LNT|brandon> uploaded a file: <https://gwusbdhdu.slack.com/files/brandon/F0DHXG057/lithium-oxygen_award.txt|Lithium-Oxygen Award> and commented: <@U0A6V6PHS>, <@U0A6Z2QE4> - posted today!

file.name: Lithium-Oxygen_Award.txt
file.title: Lithium-Oxygen Award
file.preview:
I am thrilled to announce that Professor Bryan McCloskey has won the 2015 “Science Award Electrochemistry” from BASF and Volkswagen.

(see: http://www.vwvortex.com/news/volkswagen-news/basf-and-volkswagen-present-science-award-electrochemistry-to-berkeley-researcher/)

The award announcement states in part:

"The jury of representatives from BASF, Volkswagen and from academia selected Dr. McCloskey for his outstanding research results in the area of lithium-oxygen batteries. He has analyzed the fundamental electrochemical processes in this type of battery by examining the stability of electrolytes and electrode materials. Through his work, the scientist has decisively contributed to a deeper understanding of lithium-oxygen batteries. He receives prize money of €50,000."
file.preview_highlight:
I am thrilled to announce that Professor Bryan McCloskey has won the 2015 “Science Award Electrochemistry” from BASF and Volkswagen.


(see: http://www.vwvortex.com/news/volkswagen-news/basf-and-volkswagen-present-science-award-electrochemistry-to-berkeley-researcher/)




The award announcement states in part:




"The jury of representatives from BASF, Volkswagen and from academia selected Dr. McCloskey for his outstanding research results in the area of lithium-oxygen batteries. He has analyzed the fundamental electrochemical processes in this type of battery by examining the stability of electrolytes and electrode materials. Through his work, the scientist has decisively contributed to a deeper understanding of lithium-oxygen batteries. He receives prize money of €50,000."

file.name: Compiling_on_a_Router.txt
file.title: Compiling on a Router
file.preview:
Is it possible to add a buildroot/gcc package to entware (also automake, autoconf, etc)?

Because with optware you have that and i compile small things on the router itself (is faster than crosscompiling and trasnferring everytime)!
----
In fact, Entware is OpenWRT, so no native compilation is provided. Not for now, not in future.

A modern gcc eats too much memory for running on embedded devices. We may port it without any optimisations (-O2, -O3, -Os), but it will be useless.
file.preview_highlight:
Is it possible to add a buildroot/gcc package to entware (also automake, autoconf, etc)?


Because with optware you have that and i compile small things on the router itself (is faster than crosscompiling and trasnferring everytime)!


----


In fact, Entware is OpenWRT, so no native compilation is provided. Not for now, not in future.




A modern gcc eats too much memory for running on embedded devices. We may port it without any optimisations (-O2, -O3, -Os), but it will be useless.

initial_comment.comment: so THAT'S why it's not possible!  EVERYTHING must be cross-compiled due to memory usage issues on the router.

text: Open-WRT's clearly cranking along: <https://openwrt.org/>
more clues on router cross-compilation: <https://github.com/Entware/entware/wiki/How-to-add-a-new-package-or-rebuild-the-feed>

Apparently the best way to deal with "Nigerian oil prince" sort of scams is to actually respond

The argument goes like this: hacker writes ridiculous email that only an idiot would respond to.  This actually serves as a prefilter for the hacker, who sends so many emails that he needs to make them as dumb as possible so that only the MOST GULLIBLE people respond to the initial request.  That way, the hacker doesn't waste time with people who are unlikely to give him/her actual money.

So, in order to choke the bandwidth of the hackers, everyone should respond and string them along for as long as possible, but give them nothing useful. This would quickly make this type of scam unsustainable.
(of course, no one has time to actually do this, and it would make little to no difference in the grand scheme... but it's a fun little thought experiment)

attachments.text: huginn - Build agents that monitor and act on your behalf. Your agents are standing by!

text: (yes! yes they would!)
I have it running locally
I'm setting up 'agents' and 'scenarios' to do journal aggregation and filtering on a massive scale

<@U0A6V6PHS>: Responding way back to your question on October 29th... Brandon introduced me to Linux last August and around the same time I moved from experiments into simulations. At first I was using Comsol for my simulations, but the open-source ideology took hold of me and it hasn't let go. Now I'm using entirely open-source tools for my work... I'm building an application that solves low-temperature plasma equations on top of the MOOSE (multiphysics object-oriented simulation environment), so yea... MOOSE, sage, scipy, paraview, Salome, InkScape... it's a long list of awesome tools!
Interesting. How has moose been treating you? Part of my job is running engineering simulation case studies with no budget. Currently paying with Comsol trials and chrono engine

<@U0A6T0LNT|brandon> uploaded a file: <https://gwusbdhdu.slack.com/files/brandon/F0DT1UT8R/sam_0183.jpg|Dielectric Barrier Discharge> and commented: Photos aren't great for capturing the filamentary character of air discharges, but this turned out pretty well!

initial_comment.comment: Photos aren't great for capturing the filamentary character of air discharges, but this turned out pretty well!

text: <https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=rHfVr7ohois>
Are we having fun?
testing my ideas about source design :simple_smile:

<@U0B061R88>: Nice!  Sounds like you've got the bug.  But hopefully not too many bugs.  I'm in mathematics, so I don't have the awesome scientific applications to ply with this stuff, but I've done some sporadic Sage development over the past couple of years.
<@U0A6T0LNT>: Huginn sounds *awesome*.
local setup was totally painless
looking into good ways to programmatically create 'actors'
since I have a hundred journals, and that could turn into hours of clicking

<@U0A6Z2QE4>: Moose has treated me great. It's a lot of fun to work with, and it's nice to see what goes on under the hood. I'm currently developing an interface condition between different domains that will hopefully go into the Moose framework. Trying to develop within the framework has made me realize how elegant and concise their code is.
<@U0A6V6PHS>: What type of math stuff do you do?
Algebraic and combinatorial theory of splines, i.e. differentiable piecewise polynomial approximation functions, and partition functions, i.e. the ones from statistical mechanics.
In particular, I know things about vector spaces of polynomials that represent the local structure of special classes of piecewise polynomial functions.
I don't know how much math you know, so I don't know if any of that made sense to you.

<@U0A6XP8JF> <@U0A6V6PHS> <@U0A6T0LNT> Have been processing all you guys have been saying re: awesome open software tools, and feeling a little bit like a kid looking into the window of a candy store.  <@U0A6XP8JF> says the best way to take the plunge is to start running Linux full-time (and judging by what <@U0B061R88> has been saying, that's a good approach to take).  So here are some questions/thoughts: I have a sizeable research allowance from my postdoc fellowship, and I'm thinking of using it to buy a desktop (my primary machine right now is a shitty lenovo laptop that I carried over from grad school).  So....

Question 1 (of many to come): better to buy or build?  I've never built a computer before and I feel like that's a skillset I should have.  I've helped other people build theirs by being a gopher/holding cables out of the way etc.  Too ambitious?  I don't have a good idea of the price point where buying becomes cheaper than building or vice versa.  I could probably spend $1-2k on this, with a preference for staying on the lower side.
Also interested. The HP some of you sent me in iraq is starting to show its age and battery life/keyboard fussyness has rendered it not-so-mobile.
I'm not sure if there is a price point where it becomes cheaper so much as an income level.
As for building: specifying components can be tricky. Actual assembly is pretty easy minus a few precautions like grounding yourself.
<@U0A6Z2QE4> what do you mean by price point vs. income level?  as in, maintenance/upkeep are hugely more/less expensive in one option vs. the other?

<@U0A6WE73P> I mean that it's a matter whether it's worth your time to assemble it. As a curious post doc the answer is probably yes. Also is a good idea to check with the IT department for info on tech support
If you can plug in a toaster, you can assemble a desktop computer in 2015; there are, like, six parts to plug/screw in.
<@U0A6WE73P>, <@U0B0A0NAX>, I'm super-crunched preparing for a conference next week, but I'll make it a priority to update my parts lists
Aka take care of the specs
New Google Labs project: *"Who's Down"*
it's basically a big ol' button that you hit when you wanna do something fun
I'll send you guys invites :simple_smile:
original invite courtesy of Kwasi Nti, who works at Google :simple_smile:
Are there a limited number of invites?
Niiiice.
Google, you so funny.
Lots of 1-star reviews on the Google Play store complaining about not being able to get an invite, so seems like quantities are limited, get yours while supplies last!
<@U0A6T0LNT>: What conference?
<@U0B061R88>: Carly and I are headed to AIChE in Salt Lake City!
in the 'computing education best practices' session, I'm presenting on Sage Math
and in the 'laboratory courses' session, I'm presenting on open source hardware for DIY data acquisition, analysis, and control
